description: From Middle English steem, stem, from Old English stēam (“steam, hot exhalation, hot breath; that which emits vapour; blood”), from Proto-Germanic *staumaz (“steam, vapour, breath”), from Proto-Indo-European *dʰewh₂- (“to whirl, waft, stink, shake; steam, haze, smoke”). Cognate with Scots stem, steam (“steam”), West Frisian steam (“steam, vapour”), Dutch stoom (“steam, vapour”), Low German stom (“steam”), Swedish dialectal stimma (“steam, fog”), Latin fūmus (“smoke, steam”).

entries.meaning: Old-fashioned; from before the digital age.
The vapor formed when water changes from the liquid phase to the gas phase.

definitionGroups.group: The suspended condensate (cloud) formed by water vapour when it encounters colder air

entries.meaning: mist, fog
Exhaled breath into cold air below the dew point of the exhalation
Pressurized water vapour used for heating, cooking, or to provide mechanical energy.
The act of cooking by steaming.
examples: Give the carrots a ten-minute steam.

entries.meaning: (figuratively) Internal energy for motive power.
examples: After three weeks in bed he was finally able to sit up under his own steam.

entries.meaning: (figuratively) Pent-up anger.
examples: Dad had to go outside to blow off some steam.

entries.meaning: A steam-powered vehicle.
Travel by means of a steam-powered vehicle.
(obsolete) Any exhalation.
(fencing) Fencing without the use of any electric equipment.

verbs.description: steam (third-person singular simple present steams, present participle steaming, simple past and past participle steamed)

entries.meaning: (cooking, transitive) To cook with steam.
examples: The best way to cook artichokes is to steam them.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To expose to the action of steam; to apply steam to for softening, dressing, or preparing.
(intransitive) To produce or vent steam.
(intransitive) To rise in vapour; to issue, or pass off, as vapour.
examples: Our breath steamed in the cold winter air.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, figuratively) To become angry; to fume; to be incensed.
(transitive, figuratively) To make angry.
examples: It really steams me to see her treat him like that.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To be covered with condensed water vapor.
examples: With all the heavy breathing going on the windows were quickly steamed in the car.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To travel by means of steam power.
examples: The ship steamed out of the harbour.

entries.meaning: (figuratively or literally) To move with great or excessive purposefulness.
examples: If he heard of anyone picking the fruit he would steam off and lecture them.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To exhale.
